sentences.sentence: +1 800 591 5241 +1 800 591 5241 +52 55 4165 2627 +44 20 3966 0521 +34 919 490 509 +61 251 335 555 +55 61 4042 7858 +49 80 0800 1022 Toggle navigation Why VPN Net neutrality is the simple idea that all broadband traffic be treated equally by internet service providers.
Net neutrality has been a hot-button issue since it captured the cultural zeitgeist in 2015.
While the term became corrupted in Western politics, net neutrality is far from a partisan issue.
This guide chronicles everything you need to know on net neutrality in the United States, from its pure definition, to its origins, history, and everything in between.
Put simply, net neutrality is the principle that all broadband traffic be treated equally by internet service providers.
In practice, net neutrality prevents ISPs from discriminating against specific content, websites, users, apps, platforms, devices, or communication methods.
It also bars them from creating fast and slow lanes online.
Without net neutrality laws, however, ISPs are free to form business relationships with any third parties and show bias to these partners.
These conditions harm consumers who could be asked to pay more to use their favorite services, or be prevented from viewing their favorite content entirely.

When the principle of net neutrality is government mandated and properly enforced, broadband companies cannot censor websites, block access to individual URLs, charge premiums, or throttle network traffic.
Put simply, net neutrality is the principle that all broadband traffic be treated equally by internet service providers.
In practice, net neutrality prevents ISPs from discriminating against specific content, websites, users, apps, platforms, devices, or communication methods.
It also bars them from creating fast and slow lanes online.

When the principle of net neutrality is government mandated and properly enforced, broadband companies cannot censor websites, block access to individual URLs, charge premiums, or throttle network traffic.
Without net neutrality laws, however, ISPs are free to form business relationships with any third parties and show bias to these partners.
These conditions harm consumers who could be asked to pay more to use their favorite services, or be prevented from viewing their favorite content entirely.
The term “net neutrality” was first coined by Colombia law professor, Tim Wu, in his 2003 paper .
But while net neutrality didn’t become a subject of public interest until the 21st century, the concept itself goes back much further.
In fact, it’s basically as old as the World Wide Web itself.

Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web, and when he did so, he intended it to be a “permissionless space for creativity, innovation and free expression.” As Berners-Lee puts it, “[w]hen I invented the web, I didn’t have to ask Vint Cerf for permission to use the internet.” Cerf is regarded as one the the “fathers of the internet.” He, alongside Bob Kahn, created the Internet Protocol and Transmission Control Protocol.
Without IP/TCP, the World Wide Web could not exist.
And the internet could not have evolved into the global connector we know it as now if Cerf and Kahn did not allow it to function free from discrimination.
Neutral conditions encouraged innovation online, but as the internet grew, so did business interests in it.
According to industry experts, if business interests were left unchecked, they would stifle innovation.
This fear was outlined in an open letter signed by Cerf, Berners-Lee, and dozens of their peers.
In the letter, they explain the technical hurdles a lack of net neutrality creates.
Without principles of openness and non-interference, they argue, the new technologies that rely on the internet could suffer greatly.

Net neutrality in the United States: a long, complicated history of classification Though 2014 is the year we attribute to the modern net neutrality debate in the USA, the story truly begins 80 years prior.

1934 - 2002 - Reclassification as a Title I 2010 - 2014 - Road to Reclassification 2017 - Repeal of Net Neutrality 2018 - Pushback From the Repeal 1934 - With the passing of this bill, the FCC is formed, as is the legal basis on which all future net neutrality rulings will rely on In 1934, Congress passed the .
This formed the Federal Communications Commission and tasked them with regulating the telephone, telegraph, and radio industries.
Obviously all communication technologies have since changed, but this bill laid the framework for how specific forms of telecommunication would be treated.

Crucially, the Communications Act of 1934 (and its future amendments) established seven subchapters, called ‘Titles.’ Methods of telecommunication were categorized into these titles, which stipulated how rigorously they would be regulated.
Of particular note are the distinctions between Title I and Title II.
Title I was created for “General Provisions,” or information services.
These services were to be subjected to limited scrutiny and only received light regulations.

Title II was created for “Common Carriers,” or services regarded as public utilities; Telecommunications services categorized as Title II were subjected to the strictest regulation because they were required by the entire public society to function.
They were also to remain neutral, in accordance with the following text from Sec.

202 of the bill: "It shall be unlawful for any common carrier to make any unjust or unreasonable discrimination in charges, practices, classifications, regulations, facilities, or services for or in connection with like communication service, directly or indirectly, by any means or device, or to make or give any undue or unreasonable preference or advantage to any particular person, class of persons, or locality, or to subject any particular person, class of persons, or locality to any undue or unreasonable prejudice or disadvantage."
The protections first afforded to consumers in 1934 are the basis of all net neutrality legislation, but it would be decades before the distinction between Title I and Title II came into play.
After all, when the was originally signed into law, the World Wide Web wasn’t even fathomable.

Under principles of openness, the stage is set for the globalization and commercialization of the net It’s 1989, the year commonly recognized as when Tim Berners-Lee first invented the World Wide Web at CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research).
While this was already milestone for humanity, the most critical developments regarding net neutrality occurred within the following four years.
In January 1991, the first World Wide Web servers outside of CERN were switched on.
Two years later, in March 1993, the Acceptable Use Policy of the World Wide Web was reinterpreted so as to allow commercialization of the net.

With the conditions of net neutrality functionally intact, the World Wide Web sees rapid growth and innovation The following month in April 1993, Berners-Lee and CERN announced that the World Wide Web’s underlying code would be available on a royalty-free basis forever.
This royalty-free designation was groundbreaking, because the FCC’s Title I and Title II wouldn’t apply to computer engineers using internet programs privately.
To come into play, the World Wide Web had to be made publicly available.
By making it royalty-free, CERN actively promoted the growth of the technology.

And the prior reinterpretation of the Acceptable Use Policy, of course, meant that the internet became the subject of businesses interests, making its regulation and FCC classification all the more important.
From 1993 onwards, the World Wide Web saw rapid growth.
From the advent of Web 2.0, to the dot-com bubble, and the introduction of social network services, the innovation was constant.
And it all occurred with the internet effectively functioning as a Title II service.

2002 - Reclassification as a Title I Now too big to ignore, the FCC rules on the World Wide Web, legally subjecting it to light regulation as an information service While the online boom surged through the turn of the century under Title II, everything shifted in March 2002.
With the web becoming ubiquitous, the FCC decided to reevaluate how it was regulated.
Under Chairman Michael Powell, broadband internet access provided by cable companies was reclassified as a Title I information service.
The move was impactful, as it provided ISPs with power they never had before.
But this reclassification did not completely undermine consumer freedom.
That’s because many internet users were still connecting via dial-up in 2002.
Those consumers still received Title II protections, as telephone companies were not included in the March 2002 reclassification .
Additionally, while broadband was considered an information service, the FCC took a favorable view of online freedom during this period.

In February 2004, Chairman Powell revealed “Four Internet Freedoms.” Because broadband companies were information service providers and not common carriers, however, they were not under a strict obligation to adhere to these principles.
Thankfully, though, the FCC was active in promoting online freedom.
In March 2005, the FCC publicly accused Madison River Communications of blocking customer access to VoIP.
MRC offered to cease this practice, but because they were not a common carrier, this represented a good faith agreement and not an official FCC enforcement.
The Madison River Communications agreement was promising, but it was shortly followed by another watershed moment.
On September 23, 2005, the FCC reclassified all internet service providers, including telephone companies, as Title I information services.
The move was made under new FCC Chairman Kevin Martin.

Like his predecessor, Chairman Martin outlined four neutral “Internet Principles” he wanted ISPs to honor: Consumers are entitled to access the lawful Internet content of their choice; Consumers are entitled to run applications and services of their choice, subject to the needs of law enforcement; Consumers are entitled to connect their choice of legal devices that do not harm the network; and Consumers are entitled to competition among network providers, application and service providers, and content providers.
As these principles weren’t official regulation, the FCC was limited in their capacity to enforce them.
What followed was a net neutrality back-and-forth that still continues to this day.

Without strict, enforceable rules in place, ISPs impede on user freedom with increasing regularity Despite the FCC’s pro-net neutrality stance, the internet’s Title I status made net neutrality difficult to enforce.
With ISPs unbothered by regulations to adhere to, they did their worst.
In 2007, an investigation revealed Comcast was guilty of discriminating against its users by blocking and throttling BitTorrent use.

An official FCC investigation followed, but before it reached a conclusion, Comcast and BitTorrent reached an agreement on network management that would prevent Comcast from discriminating against specific types of traffic.
Despite this collaboration, the FCC determined by a 3-2 vote that Comcast’s previous BitTorrent practices were unlawful and subject to sanctions.
In response to the blockages and throttling, the FCC officially served Comcast a cease and desist order, and required them to inform customers about traffic management in the future.
But this invited a legal challenge from Comcast, which they won.
On April 6, 2010, the US Court of Appeals tossed out the FCC’s cease and desist order, largely because Comcast’s Title I classification meant the FCC overstepped their regulation authority.

2010 - With net neutrality violations piling up, the FCC unsuccessfully attempts to curb broadband interference Undeterred by the failed Comcast lawsuit, the FCC resolved to outline clear-cut rules so as to avoid future net neutrality violations.

This led to the adoption of the on December 21, 2010, which prevented ISPs from blocking or slowing down user access to legal web content, and required transparency in regards to network management practices.
was a step in the right direction for net neutrality, but it was not without major shortcomings.
First, the new rules only applied to broadband companies, not mobile carriers.
Additionally, the rules did not prohibit providers from charging premiums for priority access.
And most importantly, the was introduced with questionable legal standing, as it did not include a reclassification of broadband as a Title II common carrier.
These drawbacks ultimately came to a head in January 2014.
Following the filing of a Verizon lawsuit against the FCC, the US Court of Appeals for the D.C.
Circuit again ruled in favor of broadband companies.
And like the Comcast case before it, the court cited the FCC’s lack of authority to enforce net neutrality due to Verizon’s Title I classification.
was not a total loss, though.
The court acknowledged that the FCC should be able to enforce FCC net neutrality rules.
But to do so, the FCC would need to establish its clear legal authority.

2014 - Road to Reclassification Learning from previous failures, the FCC makes the crucial decision to reclassify and delivers legally mandated net neutrality After the result of the Verizon case, it was clear the FCC could not keep attempting to regulate net neutrality without major changes.
In May 2014, the FCC voted 3-2 to open up Commissioner Tom Wheeler’s net neutrality proposal for public comment.
But the proposal was met with some pro-net neutrality pushback, for it would still allow fast and slow lanes to exist, and did not call for Title II reclassification.
The following month, comedian John Oliver ran a segment arguing for strict net neutrality regulations.
This was an pivotal turning point, as it introduced the debate into the public discourse.
As part of his segment, Oliver encouraged viewer to flood the FCC’s public commenting system with pro-net neutrality responses.
His call-to-action was successful, with the surge of commenters ultimately crashing the FCC website’s servers.
In total more than 4 million people had their say on the proposal.
With the public clamoring for change , President Barack Obama delivered a speech urging the FCC to preserve a “free and open internet” by reclassifying broadband as a Title II common carrier.
On February 26, 2015, the FCC voted to reclassify broadband, restoring its public utility status that encouraged web innovation to thrive in the 1990s and early 2000s.
The newly-enforceable net neutrality rules, which prevented throttling, blocking, and paid prioritization, were finally made official on April 13, 2015.
Then, they were destroyed.

2017 - Repeal of Net Neutrality With controversial new Chairman Ajit Pai now in control, the FCC wages war on online freedom and works swiftly to repeal net neutrality While the internet at-large rejoiced over net neutrality’s success, administrative changes bring new agendas.
In January 2017, newly-inaugurated President Donald Trump named FCC Commissioner Ajit Pai as the new FCC Chairman.
The choice was significant: as an FCC Commissioner, Pai voted against net neutrality in 2015.
A month before he was named chairman, he publicly stated that broadband’s status as a Title II common carrier would soon be over.
A strong proponent of deregulation, Chairman Pai spearheaded a 2017 campaign in favor of repealing net neutrality.
This campaign was fraught with controversy.
As part of the public commenting process, millions of energized citizens hit the FCC’s commenting system to argue their case for online freedom.
But the system was also riddled with millions of fake, anti-net neutrality comments from bots.
Moreover, many were left unable to access the comment system as the system was made inaccessible.
The FCC claimed they were the victims of a DDoS attack, but those claims proved totally bogus .
Despite a questionable commenting process , and a huge public outcry, the will of the people was ignored.
In December 2017, Ajit Pai’s FCC voted 3-2 to reclassify broadband as a Title I information service .
On June 11, 2018, the repeal was made official.

2018 - Pushback From the Repeal Following a repeal process that lacked transparency and ignored public wishes, net neutrality heads to the courts The internet was quick to condemn Pai’s gutting of net neutrality, and politicians followed.

Pressured by the Fight for the Future, Demand Progress, and the Free Press Action “ Battle for the Net ” project, the Senate invoked the in May 2018, before the net neutrality repeal was even made official.
This legislative loophole marked a legal attempt by Congress to reverse the FCC’s decision.
But in order to succeed, the CRA needed to pass through both houses of Congress before the Congressional session ended.
That didn’t happen.
The deadline passed before enough signatures were secured to force a CRA floor vote.
Despite Congressional failure to pass a CRA resolution, the fight for net neutrality continues.
Not content with robbing their residents of online freedom, several states have taken net neutrality into their own hands.
Washington Governor, Jay Inslee, signed a bill that made net neutrality law in his state.
Governors in and signed net neutrality executive orders, while California Governor, Jerry Brown, signed the most aggressive state net neutrality bill in the country .
California’s open internet legislation offered even more protections than the 2015 FCC net neutrality laws repeal.
Unfortunately, this prompted action from Justice Department, who sued the state of California .
But the lawsuits were not to be one-sided.
Soon after the FCC reclassified broadband as an information service, Mozilla, along with 22 state attorney generals, sued the FCC over their net neutrality repeal.
This filing not only attempts to restore neutral web conditions, it also determines whether or not states have the right to enact their own net neutrality laws.
Success would mean that California’s extended protections would be valid, but with the results of the lawsuit pending, California is deferring to the current federal law.
Ultimately, the immediate future of net neutrality hinges on these court decisions, which should be delivered later in 2019.
In addition to the pending court cases, Democrats introduced “Save the Net” bills in both the House and Senate.
These proposals would reverse the FCC’s repeal and also bar the FCC from reclassifying broadband as a Title I service again.
The bill was approved in the House, but blocked in the Senate .
Net neutrality’s future as U.S. law could depend on how the courts perceive the FCC’s behavior.
These are the questions the courts must answer.
While it’s difficult to guess what the outcome will be, the claims against the FCC have merit.
Regardless of the results, though, IPVanish supports an equal internet, and we always will.
To guarantee that open internet conditions are still achievable, we continue to invest in and expand our VPN service.
IPVanish also supports the organizations doing tireless work to restore our digital rights, and encourage our U.S. government to do the same.
These organizations include: .
If you would like to get involved, visit their websites for more information, and follow their social accounts for regular updates.
Lastly, continue pressuring Congress to protect net neutrality by contacting your representatives and senators .
To stay in touch with IPVanish as we battle for net neutrality, follow us on and , check out our blog , and visit this page for regular news developments.
